head.title: Besieged by Cell Phone, Soothed by Sonnet

hedline.hl1: Besieged by Cell Phone, Soothed by Sonnet

abstract.p: Abigal Smith letter on William Safire's June 8 column on being overconnected notes she uses her personal organizer to read poetry; drawing

block.p: Re ''Too Much in Touch,'' by William Safire (column, June 8):
Should Mr. Safire see me glancing at my Palm Pilot while I am waiting for the subway, or for my sandwich at the deli, he might be surprised to know that I am reading Shakespeare's sonnets.
Re ''Too Much in Touch,'' by William Safire (column, June 8):
Should Mr. Safire see me glancing at my Palm Pilot while I am waiting for the subway, or for my sandwich at the deli, he might be surprised to know that I am reading Shakespeare's sonnets.

Although I could carry a book of the sonnets, I have a lot fewer things to carry this way, and can even read them while waiting for a friend to arrive at one of those very dark restaurants, or waiting for a bus, or in a taxi at night. My goal is to learn a sonnet each week, and it is handy to have them at my fingertips where I can easily learn a line or two in those minutes during the day when one can take a moment to be alone.
These electronic devices can sometimes enhance one's solitary time!
ABIGAIL SMITH West New York, N.J., June 9, 2000
